byline.contributor: Susanne Craig reported from New York, and Jesse McKinley from Syracuse.
byline.original: By SUSANNE CRAIG and JESSE McKINLEY

abstract: Non-profit group Believe in Syracuse organizes picnic and swim to promote Onondaga Lake, which has reputation for extreme pollution but has now undergone years of cleanup; Environmental Conservation Dept says cleanup is going well, and commissioner Joseph Martens plans to participate in swim, but New York State Health Dept continues to warn people against eating fish from lake.
lead_paragraph: Believe in Syracuse, a booster group, has organized a swim in which the head of the Environmental Conservation Department will jump into Onondaga Lake to prove it is not as polluted as it once was.

headline.main: Despite Pollution Warnings, an Official Will Jump Into Onondaga Lake
headline.print_headline: How to Prove Lake’s Clean? Official Will Take a Swim

snippet: Believe in Syracuse, a booster group, has organized a swim in which the head of the Environmental Conservation Department will jump into Onondaga Lake to prove it is not as polluted as it once was.
